description: From Middle English twig, twyg, from Old English twiġ, from Proto-Germanic *twīgą (compare West Frisian twiich, Dutch twijg, German Zweig), from Proto-Indo-European *dweygʰom (compare Old Church Slavonic двигъ (dvigŭ, “branch”), Albanian degë (“branch”)), from *dwóh₁. More at two.

entries.meaning: A small thin branch of a tree or bush.
examples: They used twigs and leaves as a base to start the fire.

verbs.description: twig (third-person singular simple present twigs, present participle twigging, simple past and past participle twigged)

description: From Irish and Scottish Gaelic tuig (“to understand”).

verbs.description: twig (third-person singular simple present twigs, present participle twigging, simple past and past participle twigged)

entries.meaning: (colloquial, regional) To realise something; to catch on; to recognize someone or something.
examples: He hasn't twigged that we're planning a surprise party for him.

entries.meaning: To understand the meaning of (a person); to comprehend.
To observe slyly; also, to perceive; to discover.

verbs.description: twig (third-person singular simple present twigs, present participle twigging, simple past and past participle twigged)
